repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
Is the "pattern" storing anything useful? If not should it be "osc"/"dsc", so that handlers can easily ignore responses they aren't interested in?

For the `TermOSC` / `TermRequest` event in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/22159 I was thinking we would put "osc"/"dsc"/etc in the event pattern. Symmetry would be nice if possible.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -987,8 +987,8 @@ TermClose			When a |terminal| job ends.
 				Sets these |v:event| keys:
 				    status
 							*TermResponse*
-TermResponse			When Nvim receives a OSC response from the
-				terminal.  Sets |v:termresponse|. When used
+TermResponse			When Nvim receives an OSC or DCS response from
+				the terminal.  Sets |v:termresponse|. When used

comment_data.body: first parameter could be "type", then we can pass that as the event pattern (and/or a v:event key and/or a Lua callback `ev` field)

I'm not convinced we need this. The "type" of the sequence can be discerned from the sequence itself (e.g. a DCS always begins with `ESC P`). We will always include the full sequence (including the OSC/DCS prefix) so that autocommands have the ability to handle both OSCs and DCS sequences and distinguish between them. So including the "type" in the pattern doesn't provide any more information.

The TermResponse autocommand is rare and low frequency, so being able to filter out unwanted events is not that much of a benefit either.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -987,8 +987,8 @@ TermClose			When a |terminal| job ends.
 				Sets these |v:event| keys:
 				    status
 							*TermResponse*
-TermResponse			When Nvim receives a OSC response from the
-				terminal.  Sets |v:termresponse|. When used
+TermResponse			When Nvim receives an OSC or DCS response from
+				the terminal.  Sets |v:termresponse|. When used

comment_data.body: Is it a one-way door? I.e. will it be hard to change this event signature later?
Probably not. If you feel strongly about it, we can do it. But I really don't see the benefit -- it's additional complexity (in both code and documentation) that doesn't pay for itself imo.

I don't feel strongly about it, I thought it was something we already had and is easy to pass along.

Does this mean it's also not worth doing for TermRequest?

> The TermResponse autocommand is rare and low frequency

OTOH TermRequest could be very frequent, right? E.g. for decorating URLs. I can't say for sure about TermResponse, but if we can provide some future-proofing then we don't have to speculate :)

>Does this mean it's also not worth doing for TermRequest?

I think so, for the same reasons I mentioned here. Anyone that wants to handle a TermRequest autocommand already needs to know how to parse the escape sequence, and in doing so it is trivially easy to determine if it's an OSC or DCS from the sequence itself.

>OTOH TermRequest could be very frequent, right? E.g. for decorating URLs.

Maybe, I'm not as familiar with the use case for TermRequest.

comment_regular_data.body: @justinmk Let's merge this as-is to unblock https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26064. We can revisit the discussion around putting the event type in the autocmd pattern when the use case around `TermRequest` becomes clearer (nothing in this PR blocks doing that in the future and it would not be a breaking change).

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(tui): support DCS responses in TermResponse event
